content.description: Bouldery line that takes on the left side of a nasty-looking crack. A short boulder problem gets you to a no-hands stance in the scoop. From here, you can climb way right of the bolt (don't fall) and jam the gross, chossy, guano-filled crack. This is probably the only way to make the climb feel 11b. Alternatively, you can go straight up and ignore the crack using a combination of sidepulls and slimpers. This makes the climb feel tough for the grade but is nicer climbing with a safer fall. After passing the crack, there are still a couple more pumpy moves before the angle eases off and you trend leftward on sharper slab. Easy 5th-class run-out from the last bolt to anchor shared with Dig-Dug on the left.
content.protection: 7 bolts, currently equipped with fixed draws
content.location: Last overhanging line on the left, easily recognizable as the line just left of the big, guano-filled crack above a scoop.

content.description: Climb short brown streak to a anchor.

climbs.name: Uncle Michael
climbs.fa: Dani Feil, Jonathan Kessler, Nick Weicht

content.description: Uncle Michael starts up moderate angled rock with a huge underkling six feet off the ground. Continue past two yellow bands of marginal quality rock to reach a small roof at the fourth bolt. The climbing quality gets better beyond this point as the rock stays a consistent gray with a couple interesting chert formations. Continue to a double bolt stainless steel anchor at the ledge 26 meters up the wall.(This route is named in memory of a family member that passed and news of the event was received after the developing of the climb.)
content.location: Uncle Michael is located 10 feet left of a buttress made of rotten rock and 180 paces right from where the approach trail meets the cliff under the cave.

content.description: Climb Grey shelves of rock to a steeper cherty section. Finished up and left.

From the cluster of barrel cacti, start up a slight slab to a cruxy overlap on bubbly rock between the second and third bolts. Finish straight up on easier terrain. Good warmup on mostly quality rock.
content.location: To the left of the main cave, there is a more vertical section. This is the furthest left route before the large cleft in the main cliff line.

content.description: Start this route headed straight up a slight dihedral on holds facing all sorts of weird directions. Trend slightly left as you head up on slightly easier terrain. It shares an anchor with the climb to its left.
content.location: This route is left of the large cleft in the main cliff band to the left of the main cave. It is currently the second route when walking past this feature and shares anchors with the route to the left.

climbs.name: Taco Trap
climbs.fa: Dani Feil, Jonathan Kessler, Nick Weicht

content.description: Taco Trap starts up light colored rock with a low angle flared crack. Climb past two yellow bands of delicate rock before encountering a tricky sequence at a small overhang into an inside corner. Continue on enjoyable face climbing along another inside corner before stepping up and right to and enjoyable face of chert. Three more bolts will bring you to a ledge with a two-bolt anchor and a great view.
content.location: Taco Trap is located 16 feet left of a buttress made of rotten rock and 175 paces right from where the approach trail meets the cliff under the cave.

content.description: Zig-zag through a couple bolts of vertical climbing to a no-hands stance under a roof. Pull through a powerful boulder problem, make a quick clip, and do another short boulder problem before snatching a great jug-flake. Finishes on pleasant, slabbier climbing above the lip.Similar in style to Scud Missile on its left, but potentially a bit harder with a longer and more sustained crux section. Book gives it the b/c grade.
content.protection: 6 bolts, currently equipped with fixed draws.
content.location: Just left of the heavily chalked-start to the neighboring 12a. Climbs into a scoop and out of a very steep section

content.description: Climb vertical rock to a small roof, making tricky pulls to stand up over it. Continue up slightly easier but still tricky moves to the top.
content.protection: 5 bolts to rings (one of the only routes without lowering hooks)
content.location: This route is on the more vertical section of cliff line to the left of the main cave. It is the fourth route to the left of the large crack in the cliff, and the third route to the right of the large cleft in the main cliff line.

content.description: Thirty feet of Grade A choss wrangling! Start with a bolt so low you'll question its worthiness to keep you off the barrel cactus below you when you explode a flake 6 feet off the ground, moving up a slight corner. Continue gingerly testing the blocks and flakes that you are yarding on as you cruise up that sweet Southern Nevada limestone. Enjoy the ride, because it's over quick. Good route to warm up to the mental aspects of the rock quality of this cliff!
content.location: This is the first route left of the large cleft in the main cliff line, to the left of the main cave.

content.description: Easier vertical climbing to a distinct and enjoyable boulder problem on small incuts through a roof. I found it easiest to use the big hole out left after the crux, which is shared with M16. One more short but challenging section on sharp grey rock takes you to the anchors.
content.location: Just right of M16, sharing the big hole above the overhanging section.

content.description:
70M rope required, and tie knots because it barley makes it!

 Starting from a small dihedral, continue up and left on low-angle terrain with lots of loose looking/sounding rocks, and generously spaced bolts. Eventually after a ledge comes the crux - a sequence up a dihedral on some hollow-sounding holds, finishing with a top-out onto a ledge with an anchor you can't really see until you top out.
content.protection: 12(ish) bolts, generously spaced. Anchor hooks, with no gates, so not the best anchor to set up a tr on!
content.location: About 30' to the right of the end of the cave. Starts up a small dihedral, and you can sorta see how it turns onto a slab to high second and third bolts.

content.description: Getting above the first bolt might be the hardest part, and you reach up and nothing really feels like a hold. After that, pretty chill, with one or two more spots where you gotta pull out some moves. The anchor has some 'X' blocks below it, but you can avoid them by going up left or right just below the anchor.
content.protection: 5(?) bolts, to a shared anchor with chains with beefy clipy-hook things.
content.location: Left route on the shared anchor between this and Tapestry of Flaws. Goes almost straight up 5ish bolts on a slightly low-angle face.

content.description: Slightly traversing to the left. Crux in the beginning. 70m rope required.
content.location: Just to the right of Scorpion

content.description: A crag-classic.  Deemed by some to be the "king line" of the cave, this heavily manufactured route tackles the centermost and steepest section . The route generally consists of increasingly difficult boulder problems separated by decreasingly good rests. At least one knee-pad (left) is very useful to take advantage of a rest down low and up high. There is a heart-breaker redpoint crux near the top when the climb transitions from juggy, campusy roof climbing to pumpy pulls on smaller crimps.Generally considered to be lower-end 13b. Book gives it a/b.
content.location: Obvious line up the center of the cave where the approach trail deposits you. The manufactured pockets in one of the roofs can be spotted from the ground.

content.description: Climb up the vertical wall on big holds facing all the wrong ways. Feels like a vertical Rifle-style route with lots of blocks and mini-bulges. This route's bolts are slightly more spaced than other routes in the same area.
content.location: This route is on the vertical face to the left of the main cave. This route is the third from the left of the large crack in the cliff.

content.description: Climb a few bolts of vert which can be tricky without knowing the holds. Fire up into the overhanging section, snagging a jug out right to clip and shake before pulling the crux moves on good pinches. Look out for a sneaky right toe hook/cam to make this less powerful. Pull into a big hole with an easy kneebar and gear up for some run-out and sharp climbing to an anchor out left. Alternatively, you can cross to a jug out right and finish on Scud Missile to save some skin and earn the same grade.
content.protection: 5 bolts, currently all but the first have fixed draws.
content.location: Just right of the large, guano-filled crack. There is a big hole above the overhanging section which makes this route easy to identify from afar.

content.description: Start below brown niche 10' up. Climb right of niche. Follow shallow groves up and through chert wall.
Start below right edge of roof. Climb into brown groove. Anchor is above on a pillar.

Climbs a few balancy moves into a series of sika'd holds and pockets reaching a long chain draw in the mini roof. Get established and make a dunk move, establish into a short compression boulder. A friction dependent sloper guards the glory jug top out.Most skip the draw as one makes the sloper move.Belayer should be standing on the lower tier below the ramp.
content.location: Right most route of the ramp. Right of Apoc Now

content.description: A crag-classic. Bouldery climbing through the bottom bulge to great jugs underneath the next bulge. Be cautious while clipping the third bolt, as blowing it here would probably mean decking. An extended draw could make for a much easier clip from the juggy undercling. Another brief boulder problem leads to a no-hands stance below the third bulge. After a full recovery, fire through an awesome jug rail into a more technical upper crux. Finishes with fun stemming to the anchors.
content.protection: 7 bolts, with all but the first currently equipped with fixed draws.
content.location: On the left side of the cave, most easily identified by the big, chalky bulge at the first bolt.

content.description: Climb the reachy bottom into a couple of crimps and pinches on good feet. Move past a mini tufa to gain a pocket, then into an obvious glue-in chockstone. Follow a series of slots and ledges to get to a short kneebar rest with a heady clip at more mini tufas. Core up for the crux boulder on steep terrain. After some resting holds, make the last reachy moves on a compression boulder to gain glory jugs at the top. Clip at modern warfare anchors.Climb was originally graded 13d (and may still be that grade), but various tufas in the first and second roof have since broken. The route has been upgraded in the new Mojave Limestone Guidebook.
content.location: Left of the Bomb, Right of Modern Warfare, First Route at the start of the ramp/ledge

content.description: Start up a slab to a cruxy overlap on holds facing all sorts of ways. After pulling this slight bulge continue up the slab on easier terrain.
content.location: On the vertical wall to the left of the main cave, this route is the second from the left of the large cleft in the main cliff band.

content.description: Fun and bouldery.Easier but engaging vertical climbing for a few bolts leads to a good rest stance before a leftwards traverse. Head out left on big holds to a big cross off an undercling slot. This draw would is a good candidate to extend, as clipping off the jug below the undercling would be comforting. After a couple more good holds, a quick crux comes with a small slot crimp out right and a couple of left hand options overhead. Latch the mail slot jug above and enjoy the easy romp up to the anchors.
content.location: Inside the scoop around the right corner of the cave. This is the right of two routes which start inside this scoop. Currently the 2nd to last route on the right of the cliff with fixed draws. Shares an anchor with the 11b to its right.

content.description: Funky and techy vert climbing through a series of bulges. Hold and sequence-finding can be tricky on this one. The first couple of clips are a little spaced out, so move carefully through the early section. The first crux comes just up and right of the second bolt, but the climbing stays on you until the angle eases off. The climb finishes with run-out, easy 5th-class from the last bolt to an anchor that is currently shared with Whackamole to the right.
content.protection: 5 bolts, all but the first have fixed draws.
content.location: First vertical route in mostly grey rock left of the overhanging stuff. This is currently the leftmost route with fixed draws.

content.description: Climb the first 5 bolts of The Bomb. Make the first couple moves into the 2nd roof of The Bomb, but before hitting the obvious big sika’d block, traverse left from a natural (reinforced) flake, float out left into the two finger pocket of Friendly Fire. Meet at the 6th bolt of Friendly Fire and boulder up the last few cruxes. Clip at the anchors of Modern Warfare.Sustained climbing with no kneebars.
content.location: Climb the bomb to the 5th bolt, traverse left on a flake into friendly fire at the 6th bolt.

content.description:
A little oomph, or good technique, or both, will get you up past the first bolt. After than, really exploring all your hold options is the key to this slightly-awkward line.

 We tried both right and left of the bolts - right seemed a little less awk.
content.protection: 4 bolts, chain anchor with beefy clips.
content.location:
One of the shortest routes in the area, you can see the anchors just before some steeper rock that caps this climb. 4 Bolts kinda stright-up a sorta-inside corner, but noy much of a corner.

 Just left of two slightly-longer climbs that share an anchor (and 5.9 and 5.10a I believe).

content.description: Climb the first 5 bolts of Friendly Fire, make a low traverse from the ledge of FF to small tic-tac-y ledges moving right, meet at the 5th bolt of The Bomb (a bit runout). Finish on the Bomb. Consistent climbing with a pump.
content.location: Start friendly fire, finish the bomb. Link-up

content.description: The most frequently ascended route of the grade range in the cave and a good first 13a for boulderers. The climb starts out with a very fun sequence of jugs and edges to a good rest below a roof. This goes at 11+/12- and is used by some as a warmup for the harder routes. Pull up above the roof using a crimp out left and make a slightly blind huck for a drilled-out slot jug for the right hand. After sticking the throw, the crux comes immediately, consisting of a short boulder problem with a couple of options that people claim go at about V5-V7 depending on beta and body type. Most skip the first clip in this traverse. Finishes on a few easier moves to pull the lip out right.
content.protection: 10 bolts, currently equipped with fixed draws.
content.location: Left side of the cave proper, easily identified by an obvious pocket at the first bolt and a traverse section below the roof up high.

content.description: Nicely sustained with a solid pump that builds throughout. Eases off significantly around the last bolt to the anchors.Most of the other routes in this range at the cave are quite bouldery, so this one might be on the better warmups for the harder routes, and is an enjoyable endeavor in its own right.
content.protection: 7 bolts, currently fixed. Shares an anchor with Dragonborn to its left.
content.location: Right side of the scoop to the right of the main cave. This is currently the last route on the right with fixed draws.

content.description: Fragile start that leads into a thin seam/groove. Follow this up and onto the chert covered headwall.

Solid addition to the series of bouldery 12- routes at the BD cave.Starts with easy and pleasant slab climbing for a couple of bolts that quickly transitions into more vertical movement. Wander your way up to a tricky crux section at the bulge, starting with a tenuous clip off a slopey two-finger pocket, followed by some pulls off small holds and slippery feet. The climb then eases off quickly, slabbing out just before the anchors.
content.protection: 8 bolts. All but the first are currently equipped with chain draws.
content.location: First route on the right side of the cave after turning the corner.

content.description: Make bouldery moves down low with big pulls, past a crack feature with interesting grips, into easier terrain on the headwall past a beehive at the level of the DP anchors. Make some committing slab moves near the top before the 2nd roof that guards the anchors. Best climbed in the fall/winter when the bees aren't buzzing.
content.protection: Permadraws, 50m rope will make it to the ground.
content.location: Right of Dark Passenger, Left of Modern Warfare

content.description: Fun and pumpy! Boulder up to a large glue-reinforced jug, and toss up (or mono) to a crimp at the break. After a disappointing shake, take a deep breath and fire up to an obvious glued hold, and continue with big moves up enhanced pockets and sloping edges. Figure out how to rest on a flat hold because the redpoint crux comes right after.
content.location: Just left of Apocalypse Now.

content.description: With or without a kneebar pad, make your way up progressive crimps and balance tech to reach a short overhanging section aka the redpoint crux. A series of pinches and slopers guard the anchors.
content.location: On the arete to the right of the Good Cancer. To the left of COVID-19.

content.description: Typical 12- BD cave bouldering on a rope.The climb starts on a few fun, longer moves that quickly transition into easy slab for the next two bolts, with a no-hands stance just below the steep section. After resting up, head out left and use some side pulls to gain a pair of incut crimps over the bulge. A tricky boulder problem takes you through the corner and eventually out to a big left hand jug before the final bulge. Mantel onto a ledge and clip the anchors. Not very sustained, but the crux section is worthwhile.
content.location: Left-most route in the cave before it turns the corner.

content.description: A punchy start leads to sustained climbing up to a mini-roof where you'll encounter the definite crux. After sticking the crux, easier but fun and potentially tricky dihedral climbing takes you to the short slab finish. Kneebars available for those who care to use them. This climb is notably less bouldery and less manufactured than the other 13-'s, making it one of the best at the cliff.A large undercling on this climb broke on 3/27/21, and probably made this climb a bit harder although it was already considered solid in the grade.
content.protection: 7 bolts, all permadrawed. Stick clipping the 2nd bolt highly recommended.
content.location: Starts in the middle of the raised platform on the right side of the cave, on two opposing sidepull crimps at shoulder height.

content.description: One of the best at the crag!Start on big side pull ledges up and over some blocks, gaining some underclings into easier terrain. Low crux climbs like a gym boulder with all natural rock.
content.protection: 8 Bolts, no permas, Anchors at top
content.location: Clean looking face in the shade to the left of the short route (Delayed Choice Quantum Eraser) with low anchors.

content.description: Blue Diamond Cave is an impressive wall of limestone up to 200 feet tall located above Highway 160 . This crag is on the left side of a 1/2 mile + long cliff band that wraps around to the town of Blue Diamond. The wall enjoys southern exposure making it a wonderful climbing area for the cooler months. The Limestone and short approach / commute also makes this wall a good option for when moisture hits Red Rocks. The king lines and prime routes are located in the overhanging section of wall where the approach trail meets the cliff. There are numerous high quality 5.12's and 5.13's to pick from with many of the climbs enjoying fixed permadraws. To the left of the cave is about 200 feet worth of vertical technical face climbing with enjoyable 5.10's. To the right of the overhang is a never-ending ban of chaos but with substantial trundling there will surely be additional routes added to the mix.WARNING: The natural quality of the rock in and around the cave is really, really bad. It required a lot of vision and a ton of work for the original developers to turn what is essentially a giant choss pile into a fairly stacked cliff with a bunch of enjoyable routes. Even if you don't normally helmet up for sport climbing, having one on the belayer isn't a bad idea. That being said, the routes have cleaned up immensely from their natural state, thanks to trundling, traffic, and glue. Most of the rockfall will come from getting off-route or whipping onto a dirty section of rock.
